overall_perception_summary.headline: The Clinical Savior
overall_perception_summary.description: La Roche-Posay occupies the role of the emergency responder for skin. It strips away all vanity and lifestyle fluff to focus entirely on pathology correction and barrier repair. It feels like a prescription product that happens to be sold over the counter—a sterile, authoritative tool for when safety is the only metric that matters.

foundation.title: Medical Authority
foundation.description: The brand anchors its authority in the clinic, not the garden. It operates as a Healer, viewing skin conditions as pathologies to be fixed rather than flaws to be hidden. The positioning is pure Medical Authority—sacrificing aesthetic pleasure for the promise of 'baby-safe' tolerance.

identity.title: The Sterile Guardian
identity.description: There is a significant professional distance between brand and user; it behaves like a dermatologist, not a friend. Dominated by The Caregiver archetype (60%), it uses a sterile Pharma-Code visual identity (white/blue, charts) to signal absolute safety. The tone is Clinical Authority—grave, precise, and devoid of humor.

communication.title: Diagnostic Education
communication.description: The messaging targets the 'Molecule' and the 'Problem,' persuading through data and percentages (5% Panthenol) rather than emotion. The USP is The Specialist—owning the solution for specific damage (cracked, chafed). The focus is entirely on Science Education, using diagrams to prove mechanism of action.

benefits.title: Critical Restoration
benefits.description: Functionally, it acts as a Fixer, repairing broken barriers and healing wounds. The emotional payoff is Relief—the cessation of pain and anxiety. Socially, it represents The Safe Choice, allowing the user to outsource their worry to the consensus of '100,000 dermatologists.'

marker_1.slider_a_label: [SLIDER] ORIGIN OF AUTHORITY (The Source of Power)
marker_1.reasoning: Authority flows from the clinic—'Recommended by 100,000 dermatologists', 'Tribioxin Innovation', and '5% Panthenol' anchor the brand in white-coat validation (Source: 2/5 Derm-Validated). The mission is explicitly to cure pathology, not enhance beauty—terms like 'Healing Ointment', 'Therapeutic', 'Diaper rash', and 'Cracked skin' target medical issues (Goal: 1/5 Pathology Cure). Clinical authority + pathology focus = The Healer.
marker_1.evidence: Recommended by 100,000 dermatologists... Healing Ointment... Soothing Therapeutic... Cracked, chapped, chafed skin... Diaper rash

marker_2.slider_b_position_name: ▼ Approachable (Easy to find, easy to buy)
marker_2.reasoning: The scope is laser-focused on micro-correction of specific skin failures—'cracked', 'chafed', 'diaper rash', 'chemotherapy' skin (Scope: 1/5 Micro-Correction). However, the access is wide—at $18.99 on Amazon with mass distribution, it democratizes access to this high-level repair (Access: 4/5 Approachable). It makes hospital-grade care available to the average household.
marker_2.evidence: Healing Ointment... Diaper rash... Patients undergoing chemotherapy... $18.99... Amazon availability

marker_3.reasoning: The ultimate value is safety. Claims like 'Baby Safe', 'Suitable for patients undergoing chemotherapy', and 'Fragrance Free' prove the brand sacrifices aggression for absolute tolerance (Performance: 1/5 Hypoallergenic). Transparency is handled through evidence—listing 'Dimethicone 1%' and 'Panthenol 5%' as active drug facts implies a medical standard of disclosure (Transparency: 2/5 Evidence-First).
marker_3.evidence: Baby Safe... Patients undergoing chemotherapy... Fragrance Free... Dimethicone 1%... Panthenol 5%

marker_4.reasoning: The visual language is aggressively sterile—white tubes, blue text, comparison charts, and grid layouts scream 'pharmacy' not 'vanity' (Aesthetic: 1/5 Clinical Sterile). The price point ($18.99) and 'French Pharmacy' heritage elevate it slightly above commodity, but it remains a functional purchase (Value: 3/5 Masstige). It parks in the Doctor's Spot.
marker_4.evidence: White tube packaging... Blue clinical typography... Comparison Chart... Recommended by 100,000 dermatologists

marker_5.reasoning: The brand emits zero emotional heat. 'Apply cream as needed', 'Do not use on broken skin', 'TribioMa Innovation'—it is pure instruction and data (Thermostat: 1/5 Robotic). The stance is looking down from a position of superior knowledge—citing '100,000 dermatologists' and 'Clinical insights' (Power: 4/5 Specialist). It is the serious expert you trust with your baby's health.
marker_5.evidence: Apply cream as needed... Do not use on broken skin... TribioMa Innovation... Recommended by 100,000 dermatologists

marker_6.reasoning: Dominant Caregiver energy (60%) drives the mission to protect the vulnerable ('Baby safe', 'Chemotherapy', 'Healing'). The Sage (30%) provides the method ('TribioMa', 'Science', 'Dermatologist insight'). The Ruler (10%) asserts dominance (#1 brand, 'Recommended by 100,000'). Group A (Caregiver/Ruler) dominance creates The Stabilizers—offering order and safety in the chaos of skin irritation.
marker_6.evidence: Baby safe... Patients undergoing chemotherapy... Healing Ointment... TribioMa... Recommended by 100,000 dermatologists

marker_7.reasoning: The tone is grave and clinical—'In case of swallowing, get medical help', 'Do not use on broken skin'. There is no attempt at humor or casualness (Humor: 1/5 Grave). It speaks with the formality of a medical insert (Formality: 2/5 Traditional) and the flat affect of a diagnosis (Enthusiasm: 1/5 Clinical). This builds trust through distance and precision.
marker_7.evidence: In case of swallowing, get medical help... Do not use on broken skin... Temporarily protects... Soothing Therapeutic

marker_8.reasoning: The visual temperature is freezing—stark white backgrounds, medical blue text, and black warnings create a hospital aesthetic (Thermostat: 1/5 Sterile). The layout is rigid and informational, utilizing comparison charts, ingredient triptychs, and icon arrays to convey data without artistic flourish (Entropy: 1/5 Swiss Grid).
marker_8.evidence: White tube packaging... Medical blue text... Comparison Chart... Ingredient Triptych... Icon array
marker_8.look_and_feel: A sterile, high-trust environment using the visual vernacular of the pharmacy to signal safety.
marker_8.primary_palette: Clinical white foundation with medical blue accents and stark black typography for maximum legibility.

marker_9.reasoning: The hook is the result—'Healing,' 'Soothing,' 'Protecting.' It promises to fix a specific state of skin (Hook: 4/5 Result). The persuasion is purely rational, linking ingredients to outcomes ('Madecassoside for wound healing,' 'Panthenol for soothing') in a cause-and-effect structure (Persuasion: 2/5 Rational).
marker_9.evidence: Healing Ointment... Soothing Therapeutic... Madecassoside used as a therapeutic agent... Vitamin B5 helps skin feel soothed

marker_10.reasoning: The hero is the collective authority of '100,000 dermatologists,' not a founder or sufferer (Protagonist: 1/5 The Nobel). The setting is the clinic/lab, emphasized by the 'TribioMa' molecular structure imagery and 'Tribioxin Innovation' text, pushing the 'Thermal Water' source into the background of a scientific process (Setting: 1/5 Sterile).
marker_10.evidence: Recommended by 100,000 dermatologists... Tribioxin Innovation... Molecular structure imagery... Dermatologist Insight

marker_11.reasoning: Validation is top-down—'Recommended by 100,000 dermatologists worldwide' is the ultimate authority claim, overriding consumer reviews for this type of medical product (Validator: 1/5 The Board). Proof is technical—'Dimethicone 1%,' 'TribioMa,' 'Madecassoside'—relying on the customer's trust in the clinical graph and ingredient efficacy (Proof: 1/5 The Graph).
marker_11.evidence: Recommended by 100,000 dermatologists... Dimethicone 1%... TribioMa... Madecassoside... Dermatologist tested

marker_12.slider_a_label: [SLIDER] THE OWNERSHIP OBJECT (What You Claim to Own)
marker_12.slider_b_label: [SLIDER] THE TARGET SCOPE (How Wide Is The Net?)
marker_12.reasoning: The brand claims ownership of the system/complex—'Cicaplast,' 'TribioMa,' 'Tribioxin Innovation'—proprietary names for their technology (Ownership: 5/5 The System). The target is specific problem skin—'Cracked, chapped, chafed,' 'Diaper rash'—rather than general moisturizing (Scope: 4/5 The Problem).
marker_12.evidence: Cicaplast... TribioMa... Tribioxin Innovation... Cracked, chapped, chafed skin... Diaper rash

marker_13.reasoning: The content is deep education. Triptych panels explain specific ingredients like 'Madecassoside' and 'TribioMa' with molecular visuals (Depth: 1/5 Textbook). The intent is to prove safety and efficacy for vulnerable populations (babies, chemo patients), serving as a Thesis rather than a sales pitch (Intent: 1/5 The Thesis).
marker_13.evidence: Molecular structure visuals... Madecassoside explanation... TribioMa explanation... Dermatologist Insight

marker_14.reasoning: The product is a Fixer. It targets 'Cracked, chapped, chafed' skin and 'Diaper rash'—these are damage states requiring reversal, not just maintenance (Action: 5/5 The Fixer). The goal is Biological repair—restoring the 'moisture barrier' and microbiome ('TribioMa'), rather than aesthetic improvement (Outcome: 1/5 Biological).
marker_14.evidence: Healing Ointment... Cracked, chapped, chafed skin... Restore skin's moisture barrier... TribioMa... Diaper rash

marker_15.slider_a_position_name: ▼ Panic Mode (Urgent need to stop pain/itch)
marker_15.slider_b_position_name: ▼ Sanctuary (I feel safe inside my own body)
marker_15.reasoning: The emotional direction is alleviating Panic/Urgency. Terms like 'Irritated,' 'Cracked,' and 'Chemotherapy' imply a crisis state needing intervention (Anxiety: 1/5 Panic Mode). The payoff is Safety—knowing the product is 'Baby Safe' and 'Fragrance Free' allows the user to feel safe in their body again (Self-Perception: 1/5 Sanctuary).
marker_15.evidence: Irritated... Cracked... Chemotherapy... Baby Safe... Fragrance Free... Soothing

marker_16.slider_a_position_name: ▼ The Tool (I buy it only because it functions)
marker_16.slider_b_position_name: ▼ The Standard (What everyone uses; the default)
marker_16.reasoning: Purchase motivation is purely functional—you buy this because you have a problem (rash, cracks), making it a Tool, not a statement (Signal: 1/5 The Tool). Socially, it is a Standard—a mass-market staple found in pharmacies and used by 'everyone' for these issues (Tribal: 1/5 The Standard).
marker_16.evidence: Healing Ointment... Multi Purpose Cream... #2 in Body Creams... Baby Safe

marker_17.slider_a_position_name: ▼ Acceptance (I want to be accepted by the group)
marker_17.reasoning: The social goal is safety through consensus. By choosing the #2 Best Seller recommended by 100,000 dermatologists, the user accepts the group wisdom (Social Vector: 2/5 Acceptance). They join The Majority of users who trust this standard for skin repair (Group Dynamic: 1/5 The Majority).
marker_17.evidence: Recommended by 100,000 dermatologists... #2 in Body Creams... 19,428 global ratings... 4.6 stars
